title_sort: thomas jefferson whitman to walt whitman, 13 april 1863
title: Thomas Jefferson Whitman to Walt Whitman, 13 April 1863
text: Brooklyn, N. Y.April 13th/63Dear Walt,We hardly know what to think of not hearing from you  we certainly expected to have a letter from you this morning. Mother is quite anxious and of course fears that something has happened to you. Walt write to me at once wont you. I have written you two letters, one containing the $10 that Van Anden owed you, and another I mailed you last Sat. eve. Mother gave me a letter to mail you on Monday but I forgot it till to-day. You must not tell mother about it. We are all well and as jolly as usual. Andrew does not seem to get much better. He was at our house to-day to dinner  his voice is still so that you can hardly here him speak. We had a letter from George yesterday. He was at Mt Sterling Ken. He seems to feel quite well and satisfied. Mother had a letter from Heyde. He says that she must fix up her third story room for Han an him and a lot of stuff. He says that Han must come home. He says that Han wants him to take a house and let her take a man and wife to board. He wants to know what he shall do with his business. How should he get along. All of which I am sure I dont[don't] know how Mother can answer him. He is a case. I dont[don't] know what to think abtabout him. Walt I havnt[havn't] time to write you a long letter, and indeed I havnt[havn't] anything to write about. I hope to hear from you soon. All send their love, Hattie particularly.affectionately, Jeff. Thomas Jefferson Whitman to Walt Whitman, 13 April 1863
